remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Good morning, thank you for coming in today. I understand you’ve been experiencing weakness and generalized clinical examination aching, especially in your back, legs, and jaw. Could you describe if these symptoms have changed in intensity or location since they began two days ago?

remedi_labels.value: Good morning, thank you for coming in today.
weakness and generalized aching, especially in back, legs, and jaw
change in intensity or location of symptoms since onset two days ago

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Good morning, doctor. Um, yes, I’ve mostly just been feeling really weak, and the aching in my body—especially my back and legs—hasn’t really let up. I guess it’s about the same since it started. I’m also having some, uh, intermittent shortness of breath. I’m just worried because I don’t usually feel like this.

remedi_labels.value: worried because I don’t usually feel like this

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—these symptoms sound quite uncomfortable, especially since they’re not typical for you. To help guide my assessment, can you tell me if you’ve had any fever, chills, or signs of infection along with your weakness and clinical examination aches?

Um, I don’t think I’ve had a fever or chills, at least not that I’ve noticed. It’s really just this weakness that’s been bothering me the most. I’m just not sure what’s causing it, and it’s making me a bit anxious.

I can understand why you’d feel anxious about these symptoms, especially since the weakness and myalgias are new for you. To help with my clinical assessment, could you tell me if you’ve noticed any swelling in your legs, difficulty moving your muscles, or any changes in your ability to perform daily activities since these symptoms began?

remedi_labels.value: changes in your ability to perform daily activities

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um… I haven’t really noticed any swelling in my legs. Moving around is just harder because of the weakness and these, uh, myalgias—my whole body aches, but it’s definitely worst in my back, legs, and jaw. I guess I just feel this overall malaise, like I don’t have any energy to do much. Even simple symptoms, like getting up or making something to eat, feel a lot more difficult than usual.

remedi_labels.value: whole body aches, worst in back, legs, and jaw

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Thank you for explaining how these symptoms are affecting your daily activities. Given your report of poor oral intake over several weeks, can you tell me if you’ve experienced any nausea, vomiting, or changes in your appetite that might be contributing to your decreased nutritional intake?

Um, well… I haven’t really had much of an appetite lately, and I guess that’s why my oral intake has been pretty poor. I don’t think I’ve had any vomiting, but sometimes I feel a little queasy—maybe mild nausea, but nothing too severe. Actually, I did notice that when I stand up, I sometimes feel a bit lightheaded, and I think my blood pressure might be low—hypotension, right? That’s been making me more worried, to be honest.

I can understand why you’d be worried, especially with the combination of weakness, myalgias, poor oral intake, and episodes of lightheadedness. To further guide my assessment, have you noticed any changes in your urine output or color, or any new swelling that might suggest fluid retention or changes in your renal function?

Well, since I’m on hemodialysis, I don’t really make much urine anymore, so I haven’t noticed any changes there. As for swelling, um… I don’t think I’ve had any new swelling in my legs or anywhere else. I do try to keep an eye on that because of my renal function issues. But mostly it’s just this weakness and the malaise that’s been getting worse, and the lightheadedness when I stand up. Should I be worried that something more serious is going on?

I can understand why you’d feel anxious, especially given your history of multiple myeloma, amyloidosis, and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis. To help with my clinical assessment, have you noticed any new muscle tenderness, cramping, or weakness that is different from your usual symptoms, or any difficulty with chewing or jaw movement given your report of myalgias in the jaw?

Let me think… Well, the muscle tenderness is definitely more noticeable than usual, especially in my legs and back. I haven’t really had cramping, but the weakness just feels a lot worse than what I’m used to. As for my jaw, yeah, there’s this aching when I chew—sometimes it almost feels like my jaw gets tired really quickly, which is new for me.

Actually, I also wanted to mention that I’ve noticed my heart seems to be beating faster than normal—tachycardia, I think? It’s not pounding, but it’s definitely more rapid, even when I’m just sitting. Is that something I should be worried about with everything else going on?

remedi_labels.value: Is tachycardia something I should be worried about with everything else going on?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially with your symptoms of increased muscle tenderness, jaw fatigue, and tachycardia. To further guide my assessment, have you experienced any chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath that is worsening or different from your usual symptoms during your clinical course?

Well, um… I haven’t really had chest pain, but I do notice my heart racing sometimes—so I guess that would be palpitations? The shortness of breath is there, but it kind of comes and goes. It’s not really worse than usual, but it does make me a little more anxious when it happens, especially with everything else going on.

Is it possible that all these symptoms—like the tachycardia, myalgias, and weakness—are connected to my multiple myeloma or amyloidosis? Or could it be something else entirely? I just want to make sure I’m not missing something serious.

I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially given your medical history and the new onset of myalgias and poor oral intake. To help with my clinical assessment, have you noticed any changes in your mental status—such as confusion, difficulty concentrating, or increased drowsiness—since these symptoms began?

remedi_labels.value: changes in mental status (confusion, difficulty concentrating, increased drowsiness)

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Let me think… Actually, I have felt a bit more tired than usual—maybe a little drowsy at times, but I haven’t really noticed any confusion or trouble concentrating. I’m still able to follow conversations and keep track of symptoms, but I just feel kind of worn out and not quite myself. 

Is increased drowsiness something I should be concerned about with my symptoms? I know with my medical history—multiple myeloma, amyloidosis, and being on hemodialysis—symptoms can get complicated. Should I be watching out for certain warning signs, or is this just part of what’s going on?

I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially given your complex medical history and the increased drowsiness you’ve described. Based on your symptoms of generalized myalgias, poor oral intake, intermittent shortness of breath, tachycardia, and your recent laboratory findings showing elevated potassium and phosphate, I am concerned about possible metabolic disturbances or an underlying acute process. Have you experienced any recent infections, fevers, or signs of systemic illness that might suggest an acute exacerbation or complication related to your underlying conditions?

remedi_labels.value: possible metabolic disturbances or an underlying acute process
recent infections, fevers, or signs of systemic illness
acute exacerbation or complication related to underlying conditions

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Thank you for explaining all that, doctor. Um, I haven’t really noticed any fevers or obvious signs of infection—no chills, cough, or anything like that. I do feel pretty run down and, like I mentioned, just more drowsy and weak than usual. But nothing that really felt like a systemic illness, at least not in the way I usually think of it.

With these metabolic disturbances you mentioned—like the high potassium and phosphate—should I be worried about something serious happening? Could this be related to my kidneys not working well, or is it more likely from my multiple myeloma or amyloidosis? I guess I’m just anxious because I don’t want to miss something important. Are there any warning signs I should watch for?

remedi_labels.value: no fevers, no chills, no cough, no obvious signs of infection
feeling run down, more drowsy and weak than usual
should I be worried about something serious happening due to metabolic disturbances
could this be related to my kidneys not working well or from multiple myeloma or amyloidosis
are there any warning signs I should watch for

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious, especially with your complex medical history and these new symptoms of weakness, myalgias, and increased drowsiness. Based on your recent laboratory findings—particularly the elevated potassium and phosphate—these metabolic disturbances may be related to your end-stage renal disease and reduced clearance during hemodialysis, but they can also be influenced by your multiple myeloma or amyloidosis. To help guide my assessment, have you noticed any muscle twitching, numbness, or tingling, which can sometimes occur with electrolyte imbalances?

Let me think for a second… Actually, now that you mention it, I have noticed a little bit of tingling in my hands and feet over the past day or so. It’s not constant, but it kind of comes and goes. I haven’t really had muscle twitching, though—just that tingling and maybe a little bit of numbness sometimes, especially when I’m sitting still.

Is that something I should be really worried about with my potassium and phosphate being high? I know electrolyte imbalances can be dangerous, especially with my heart and kidneys the way they are. Should I be doing anything differently, or is there something specific you’ll be looking for during my assessment?

remedi_labels.value: numbness sometimes, especially when sitting still
concern about tingling and numbness related to high potassium and phosphate
asking if anything should be done differently
asking if there is something specific the doctor will look for during assessment

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially with your medical history and the recent findings of elevated potassium and phosphate. Based on your symptoms of weakness, myalgias, intermittent shortness of breath, drowsiness, and new tingling and numbness, I am concerned about the effects of electrolyte imbalances on your neuromuscular and cardiac function. During my clinical assessment, I will carefully examine your heart rhythm and neurological status—have you noticed any episodes of irregular heartbeat or skipped beats in addition to the tachycardia and palpitations you described?

remedi_labels.value: recent findings of elevated potassium and phosphate
effects of electrolyte imbalances on neuromuscular and cardiac function
episodes of irregular heartbeat or skipped beats

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Thank you for explaining all of that, doctor. Um, let me think… I don’t think I’ve noticed any really irregular heartbeats or skipped beats—at least nothing that stood out to me. It’s mostly just been the tachycardia and palpitations, like my heart is beating faster than usual, but not really out of rhythm. I guess sometimes it feels a little fluttery, but I’m not sure if that counts as irregular.

I am pretty anxious about all these symptoms, especially with the electrolyte imbalances you mentioned. Should I be worried about something happening to my heart or nerves because of the high potassium and phosphate? Is there anything I should do right now to help lower those levels, or is it just a matter of adjusting my hemodialysis? And are there any warning signs I should watch for while I’m waiting for treatment?

ways to lower potassium and phosphate levels
warning signs to watch for while waiting for treatment

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious, especially with your symptoms and the recent laboratory findings of elevated potassium and phosphate. While we proceed with your clinical assessment and treatment, have you experienced any sudden onset of chest pain, severe muscle weakness, or difficulty breathing since your last dialysis session?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially with your complex medical history and the recent symptoms of weakness, myalgias, and electrolyte imbalances. Based on my clinical assessment, your elevated potassium and phosphate are most likely related to your end-stage renal disease and will require prompt adjustment of your hemodialysis regimen, along with close monitoring for any progression of symptoms. While we address this, please notify us immediately if you develop acute chest pain, sudden severe muscle weakness, difficulty breathing, or any changes in mental status, as these could indicate serious complications. Have you had any recent changes in your dialysis schedule or missed treatments that might have contributed to these laboratory findings?
